# Complete APA 7th Edition Citation Guide Master APA 7th edition citation format with comprehensive examples and guidelines --- ## Table of Contents 1. [Quick Summary](#tldr---quick-summary) 2. [Introduction](#introduction) 3. [Understanding Apa 7Th Edition Complete Guide](#understanding-APA-7th-edition-complete-guide) 4. [Comprehensive Examples](#comprehensive-examples) 5. [Common Errors to Avoid](#common-errors-to-avoid) 6. [Validation Checklist](#validation-checklist) 7. [Frequently Asked Questions](#frequently-asked-questions) 8. [Related Resources](#related-resources) --- ## TL;DR - Quick Summary

⚡ Key Points

  • Master APA 7th edition citation formatting
  • Identify and fix common citation errors
  • Use validation tools to ensure accuracy
  • Understand the rules that matter most
  • Save time and improve your grades
--- ## Introduction Navigating the world of academic writing can be daunting, especially when it comes to understanding the intricacies of citation formats. If you are feeling confused about the differences between APA 7th edition and its predecessor, the APA 6th edition, you are not alone. Many students and researchers face similar challenges, particularly when it comes to the complex citation rules and the potential for missing required elements. This APA citation guide aims to clarify the rules and formats you need to follow when using the APA 7th edition. We will cover essential topics such as proper author formatting, how to cite works with multiple authors, and the correct use of organizational names as authors. By breaking down these elements into manageable sections, you will gain a clearer understanding of APA formatting and citation rules. One of the key changes in APA 7th edition is how to format citations for single authors, multiple authors, and works with 21 or more authors. For instance, you will learn the correct way to format a single author's name, which involves inverting the last name and using initials without spaces. You will also discover the proper use of the ampersand when listing two authors, as well as the new guidelines for works with three to twenty authors, a significant shift from the previous edition. Additionally, we will address common errors that many encounter, such as omitting required elements, misusing punctuation, and the confusion surrounding the use of "et al." By providing clear examples and explanations, this guide will help you avoid pitfalls and improve the accuracy of your citations. As you delve into this comprehensive APA citation guide, remember that you are not just learning about formatting rules. You are also enhancing your academic writing skills and ensuring that you give appropriate credit to the authors whose work shapes your own. Let us embark on this journey together to demystify APA 7th edition and empower you to produce well-cited academic work with confidence. --- ## Understanding Apa 7Th Edition Complete Guide ## Comprehensive Guide to APA 7th Edition Citation Rules The American Psychological Association (APA) 7th edition citation style is widely used in the social sciences and beyond. This guide provides a comprehensive overview of essential citation rules, ensuring that your references are formatted correctly. Following these rules helps maintain academic integrity and allows readers to locate the sources you used. ### Author Formatting #### Single Author Format When citing a single author, the correct format requires the last name followed by a comma and the first and middle initials. Each initial should be separated by periods, but there should be no spaces between them. **Correct Examples:** - Johnson, M. K. - Williams, R. A. **Common Errors:** - Not inverting the name (first name first) - Omitting the comma after the last name - Adding spaces between initials This rule ensures consistency across all reference types, including journal articles, books, and webpages. #### Two Authors Format For works with two authors, both names should be inverted and separated by an ampersand (&) rather than the word "and." Each author's name follows the same format as a single author. **Correct Examples:** - Smith, J. D., & Brown, A. M. - Garcia, L. P., & Martinez, R. T. **Common Errors:** - Using "and" instead of "&" - Not inverting the second author's name - Missing a comma before the ampersand This distinction is key for maintaining proper citation style. #### Three to Twenty Authors When there are three to twenty authors, list all authors in the reference list. Each author's name should be inverted, and authors should be separated by commas, with an ampersand before the last author. **Correct Examples:** - Anderson, K. L., Williams, J. M., Davis, S. R., & Thompson, B. P. - Chen, X., Rodriguez, M., Johnson, L., Kim, S., & Patel, R. **Common Errors:** - Using "et al." prematurely - Using "and" instead of "&" - Not listing all authors This rule represents a significant change from the previous edition, allowing for proper attribution to all contributors. #### Twenty or More Authors For works with twenty-one or more authors, list the first nineteen authors, insert an ellipsis (...), and then list the final author's name. This rule prevents extremely long citation lists while ensuring key attribution information is provided. **Correct Example:** - Author1, A. A., Author2, B. B., Author3, C. C., Author4, D. D., Author5, E. E., Author6, F. F., Author7, G. G., Author8, H. H., Author9, I. I., Author10, J. J., Author11, K. K., Author12, L. L., Author13, M. M., Author14, N. N., Author15, O. O., Author16, P. P., Author17, Q. Q., Author18, R. R., Author19, S. S., ... LastAuthor, Z. Z. **Common Errors:** - Using "et al." instead of the ellipsis format - Listing too many authors - Omitting the final author This modification offers a more comprehensive listing of authors compared to the previous edition. ### Organization as Author When an organization is the author, use the full official name. Do not invert organizational names or use initials unless they are widely known abbreviations. **Correct Examples:** - American Psychological Association - National Institute of Mental Health **Common Errors:** - Using abbreviations instead of full names - Inverting organizational names - Using acronyms without explanation This rule ensures clear attribution for corporate and institutional authors. ### Handling Missing Author Information If author information is incomplete, use available details. If only initials are available, use them without periods. If no author can be identified, move the title to the author position. **Correct Examples:** - SJ (Ed.). (2020). The complete guide. - Annual report of the company. (2019). **Common Errors:** - Using periods with initials only - Leaving the author position empty - Not using proper editor designation This guideline allows references to be created even with incomplete information. ### Date Formatting #### Basic Year Format In APA 7, the publication year is placed in parentheses following the author name and is followed by a period. **Correct Examples:** - Smith, J. (2023). Research methods in psychology. - Johnson, A. B., & Williams, C. (2022). Statistical analysis for social sciences. **Common Errors:** - Missing parentheses around the year - Incorrect punctuation after the year - Using copyright year instead of the actual publication year This rule helps clarify when the work was published. #### No Date Format When no publication date is available, use (n.d.) in place of the year in parentheses. This abbreviation stands for "no date." **Correct Examples:** - Ancient Writing Institute. (n.d.). Cuneiform tablet translations. - Author, A. (n.d.). Untitled manuscript. **Common Errors:** - Using "no date" instead of "n.d." - Missing parentheses around "n.d." - Placing "n.d." in the wrong position Following this format helps maintain clarity when no date is available. ### Conclusion Understanding and applying the rules of APA 7th edition citation is crucial for academic writing. Proper citation not only gives credit to original authors but also enables your readers to trace back the sources you referenced. Common pitfalls can be avoided by carefully following the guidelines outlined in this guide. Always double-check your formatting and remain aware of the specific rules related to authorship, dates, and organizational citations to enhance the quality of your academic work. --- ## Comprehensive Examples
The impact of social media on adolescent mental health: A longitudinal study
Chen, L., & Williams, K. (2023). The impact of social media on adolescent mental health: A longitudinal study. Journal of Abnormal Psychology, 132(4), 456-468. https://doi.org/10.1037/abn0000789
In-Text Citations:
  • Parenthetical: (Chen & Williams, 2023)
  • Narrative: Chen and Williams (2023)

Source Type: journal_article

Remote learning effectiveness during COVID-19: A meta-analysis
Johnson, M. R., Davis, S. L., & Thompson, A. K. (2022). Remote learning effectiveness during COVID-19: A meta-analysis. Review of Educational Research, 92(3), 412-445. https://doi.org/10.3102/00346543221075623
In-Text Citations:
  • Parenthetical: (Johnson et al., 2022)
  • Narrative: Johnson, Davis, and Thompson (2022)

Source Type: journal_article

In-Text Citations:

  • Narrative: Anderson et al. (2023)

Thompson, C. R., Lee, J. H., Wang, Y., Anderson, M. D., & Singh, P. K. (2020). Cognitive decline in aging: The role of physical exercise. Neuropsychology, 34(7), 892-904. https://doi.org/10.1037/neu0000654

  • Narrative: Thompson et al. (2020)

Wilson, E. J., Park, S. M., & Rodriguez, L. A. (2021). Implicit bias in hiring decisions: A meta-analytic review. Journal of Applied Psychology, 106(8), 1123-1145. https://doi.org/10.1037/apl0000987

Patel, R. K., Nguyen, T. L., Williams, J. H., Brown, C. M., & Davis, S. R. (2022). Cultural competence in teacher preparation programs. Teaching and Teacher Education, 117, 103712. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tate.2022.103712

In-Text Citations:

--- ## Validation Checklist

Use this checklist to verify your citations before submission:

  • In APA 7th edition, single authors are formatted with last name followed by a comma and first and middle initials. The initials should be separated by periods but not spaces. This format applies to all reference types including journal articles, books, and webpages. The author's name should be inverted (last name first) in the reference list only. This rule ensures consistency across all citation formats and makes alphabetical ordering more efficient in reference lists.
  • For works with two authors, both names should be inverted (last name first) and separated by an ampersand (&) rather than the word 'and'. Each author's name follows the single author format (Last name, initials). The ampersand should be preceded by a comma. This format is used in both reference lists and parenthetical citations, but narrative citations use 'and' instead of '&'. This rule distinguishes APA from other citation styles and maintains consistency across multi-author works.
  • For works with three to twenty authors, list all authors in the reference list. Each author's name should be inverted (last name first) with initials. Authors should be separated by commas, with an ampersand (&) before the final author's name. This represents a significant change from APA 6th edition, which used 'et al.' for works with seven or more authors. This rule ensures proper attribution to all contributors while maintaining readability for moderately sized author groups.
  • For works with 21 or more authors, list the first 19 authors, insert an ellipsis (...), then list the final author. The ellipsis replaces authors 20 through the second-to-last author. All listed authors follow the standard inverted format. This rule prevents extremely long citation lists while still providing key attribution information. The ellipsis should not be italicized or bracketed. This change from APA 6th edition's 7+ author rule provides more comprehensive author listing.
  • When an organization, corporation, or government agency is the author, use the full official name of the organization. Do not invert organizational names or use initials unless the organization is commonly known by its abbreviation (like APA or NIH). The organization name should be written out completely in the first mention, with abbreviations in brackets if they will be used subsequently. This rule ensures proper attribution for corporate and institutional authors while maintaining clarity for readers.
  • Author titles, suffixes, and credentials (like Jr., Sr., II, III, Ph.D., M.D.) should be included in the reference list. Suffixes like Jr., Sr., II, and III follow the initials, separated by commas. Academic and professional credentials are generally omitted from reference list entries but may be included in special circumstances. Titles like Dr., Professor, or military ranks are not included in reference list citations. This rule provides complete identification when needed while avoiding unnecessary credential inflation.
  • Authors with double surnames (like Hernandez Lopez or Van der Wiel) should maintain both parts of the surname in the reference list. Treat the double surname as a single unit with a comma after the complete surname. Do not insert commas between parts of compound surnames unless that is the person's preferred usage. This rule respects cultural naming conventions and ensures accurate identification of authors with complex surnames.
  • When author information is incomplete, use available information and follow specific rules for missing elements. If only initials are available, use them without periods. If no author can be identified, move the title to the author position. For edited volumes with no author, use the editor(s) with '(Ed.)' after the name. This rule ensures that references can be created even with incomplete author information while maintaining APA format consistency.
  • In APA 7, the publication year for most sources is placed in parentheses following the author name. The year is followed by a period. This format applies to journal articles, books, and most other standard reference types. The year should be the actual publication year, not the copyright year when they differ. For edited books, use the year of publication of the specific edition you are citing. This format has remained consistent from APA 6 with minor clarification about copyright vs publication year.
  • When no publication date is available, use (n.d.) in place of the year in parentheses. This abbreviation stands for 'no date' and is used for sources that lack any publication date information. This applies to web pages with no date, undated manuscripts, or archival materials without clear dating. The (n.d.) appears in the same position as the year would and is followed by a period. This format is unchanged from APA 6, but APA 7 provides clearer guidance on when to use (n.d.) versus seeking approximate dates.
--- ## Frequently Asked Questions ### What is the basic format for an APA reference list? An APA reference list should begin on a new page at the end of your document. The title should be centered and bolded, labeled as 'References.' Entries should be listed in alphabetical order by the surname of the first author. Each entry must have a hanging indent, which means the first line is flush left, and subsequent lines are indented. Include the author's last name, initials, publication year in parentheses, title in italics (with only the first word capitalized), and the source information. For example, a book citation would appear as follows: Lastname, A. A. (Year). Title of work. Publisher. For more detailed guidelines, refer to the APA Publication Manual or the Purdue OWL website. ### How do I cite a website in APA format? Citing a website in APA format requires including the author's name, publication date, title of the webpage, website name, and URL. For example: Author, A. A. (Year, Month Day). Title of webpage. Website Name. URL. If there is no publication date, use 'n.d.' for 'no date.' If the author is an organization, list the organization as the author. Make sure to check that the URL is accessible and formatted correctly. Additionally, if the webpage is likely to change over time, you may want to include the retrieval date. For further details, visit the APA Style website. ### What is the difference between a primary and secondary source in APA? In APA style, a primary source is an original work that has not been altered or interpreted by others. Examples include research articles presenting original data, interviews, and diaries. A secondary source, on the other hand, analyzes or interprets primary sources. For instance, a review article discussing multiple studies or a biography summarizing someone’s life is a secondary source. When using secondary sources, it is important to cite both the original work and the secondary source. For example, if you read about a study in a review article, you would cite the review article but mention the original study in your text. For more clarity, refer to the APA Publication Manual. ### How do I format in-text citations in APA style? In-text citations in APA style can be formatted in two ways: parenthetical and narrative. For parenthetical citations, include the author's last name and year of publication in parentheses after the referenced material, for example, (Smith, 2020). In narrative citations, incorporate the author's name into the text, followed by the year in parentheses, such as 'Smith (2020) found that…'. If you are citing a specific quote, include the page number as well, for example, (Smith, 2020, p. 15). If there are two authors, include both names separated by an ampersand, while for three or more, list the first author's name followed by 'et al.' For more information, consult the APA Publication Manual or the APA Style website. ### How do I cite a book with multiple authors in APA format? When citing a book with multiple authors in APA format, the citation depends on the number of authors. For a book with one or two authors, list both authors' last names and initials, separated by an ampersand. For example: Lastname, A. A., & Lastname, B. B. (Year). Title of work. Publisher. For books with three or more authors, list only the first author's name followed by 'et al.' For example: Lastname, A. A., et al. (Year). Title of work. Publisher. Remember to use italics for the title of the work and capitalize only the first word of the title and subtitle. For additional details, you can refer to the APA Publication Manual. ### What should I do if there is no author for a source I want to cite? If there is no author for a source, begin the citation with the title of the work. The title should be in italics followed by the publication date. For example: Title of work. (Year). Publisher. If the title is long, you can shorten it in your in-text citation. For instance, if the title is 'Understanding the Basics of APA Style,' you can refer to it in your text as ('Understanding the Basics,' Year). If the source is a webpage without a clear author, you can use the organization name as the author if applicable. For further guidance, check the APA Publication Manual. ### How do I cite a journal article with a DOI in APA style? To cite a journal article with a DOI in APA style, include the author's last name, initials, publication year in parentheses, article title, journal name in italics, volume number in italics, issue number in parentheses (not italicized), page range, and the DOI. For example: Lastname, A. A. (Year). Title of the article. Title of the Journal, Volume(Issue), page range. https://doi.org/xxxxx. Make sure to format the DOI as a clickable link. If the article does not have a DOI and is retrieved from an academic database, you do not need to include a URL. For detailed examples, consult the APA Publication Manual or the APA Style website. ### How can I avoid plagiarism when using APA style? To avoid plagiarism when using APA style, ensure that you properly attribute all sources of information, whether you are paraphrasing or quoting directly. Always provide in-text citations whenever you use someone else's ideas or findings. Familiarize yourself with the rules for paraphrasing and quoting. When quoting directly, include page numbers in your citations. Additionally, keep a detailed record of your sources while conducting research to make citation easier. Lastly, consider using plagiarism detection software to check your work before submission. For further guidance on avoiding plagiarism, refer to the APA Publication Manual or various academic integrity resources. ### What is the correct way to cite a government report in APA format? When citing a government report in APA format, start with the name of the government agency as the author, followed by the publication year in parentheses. Then, include the title of the report in italics, the report number (if applicable), and the publisher (if different from the author). Finally, provide the URL if the report is available online. For example: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. (Year). Title of the report (Report No. xxx). URL. If there is no report number, simply omit that part. For further examples and details, refer to the APA Publication Manual or the APA Style website. ### How do I format my paper according to APA style? To format your paper according to APA style, start with a title page that includes the title, your name, and the institution name centered on the page. The main body of your paper should have 1-inch margins on all sides, double spacing, and a readable font such as 12-point Times New Roman. Include a page header (also known as a running head) at the top of each page, which consists of a shortened version of your title and the page number. Use headings to organize your content, with different levels of headings formatted according to APA guidelines. For comprehensive formatting instructions, consult the APA Publication Manual or the APA Style website. ### What is the purpose of the abstract in an APA paper? The abstract in an APA paper serves as a brief summary of your research. It typically ranges from 150 to 250 words and should include the main research question, methods, results, and conclusions. The abstract should be placed on a new page right after the title page, with the heading 'Abstract' centered and bolded. Avoid citations in the abstract and focus on summarizing the key components of your study. This allows readers to quickly understand the essence of your work and decide whether to read the full paper. For detailed guidelines on writing an abstract, refer to the APA Publication Manual. --- ## Related Resources - [APA Citation Checker](/checker/) - [Common APA Errors](/guides/common-errors/) - [APA Style Guide](/guides/apa-style/) --- **Last Updated:** 2025-10-14 **Reading Time:** 25 minutes ---
